Let's examine the word "science"
 http://www.m-w.com/cgi-bin/dictionary?book=Dictionary&va=science
 
 1 : the state of knowing : knowledge as distinguished from ignorance or misunderstanding
 2 a : a department of systematized knowledge as an object of study <the science of theology< 
 3 a : knowledge or a system of knowledge covering general truths or the operation of general laws especially as obtained and tested through scientific method 
 b : such knowledge or such a system of knowledge concerned with the physical world and its phenomena : NATURAL SCIENCE
 =======================================================
 
 Let's then examine the word "knowledge":
 
 http://www.m-w.com/cgi-bin/dictionary?book=Dictionary&va=knowledge
 1. Knowledge
 2 a (1) : the fact or condition of knowing something with familiarity gained through experience or association 
 (2) : acquaintance with or understanding of a science, art, or technique b (1) : the fact or condition of being aware of something  
 (2) : the range of one's information or understanding <answered to the best of my knowledge< c : the circumstance or condition of apprehending truth or fact through reasoning  
 
 ========================================================
 - Science is the body of knowledge humans have put together
 - Reason is the method of separating what's true, from what's false, and thus, the method for obtaining all knowledge.
 
 Why is it that so many people argue against science (such as biology-evolution, geology-age of earth, cosmology- big bang), without first accepting or rejecting what science is defined as? Why even argue about evolution, if the real objection is with the word "science", and "knowledge"?
 
 Knowledge is the truth we have separated from falsehood. There is no exclusion here. There are no other ways presented to acquire knowledge, and there is no other knowledge. There ARE things like "faith" and faith-based beliefs, but these things do not qualify as knowledge, and are not based on reason. Just as contradictions or false beliefs don't qualify as knowledge.
 
 For instance: the claim that 2 is an odd number.
 Is this "knowledge"? Of course not.
 The US is currently at war with Japan. Is this knowledge? Of course not.
 
 2 is an even number..is this knowledge? Certainly.
 The US is currently fighting a "war on terror" in Iraq. Is this knowledge? Sure.
 
 Note: thought, ideas, concepts, are not by definition "knowledge".
 They are, thoughts, ideas, concepts. Not until they are reasonably justified as true can they be claimed as knowledge. And all such claims to knowledge are open to being falsified, that is, knowledge you think you have, might not be knowledge in practice.
 
 Note2: Unjustified, or unjustifiable beliefs cannot be claimed as knowledge (unless of course you deny the definition of knowledge, which no doubt, we'll have some takers for).
 
 Note3: Why is "science of theology" presented? Because someone screwed up? Not really. Studying how individuals and communities use and intereperet faith is real, their behavior and claims are observable, and can be falsified as having happened or not. The study, of that, on the whole can be termed "science". Theology, is, however, also based on faith, which means the claims/beliefs of theology are not knowledge necessarily. But knowledge of what they claim...is knowledge. Clear yet?
 
 ==========================================
 
 Do people really claim the definition of knowledge is just, incorrect, that man can really know the unknowable, and that there is no need to justify beliefs? YES! There are people like this...they often hide behind the very concepts they deny (the irony). They proceed to use words with definitions (acquired through reason), use logic (basic concepts of identify, etc.), but then deny these very methods they depend on to communicate their objection.
 
 Simplified:
 
 Lack of knowledge is ignorance. 
 
 To decry science/knowledge, is to praise ignorance.
 To teach creation in a school would be to teach ignorance.
 
 Some may be offended by this, but why? When it's said in such plain terms, there is always complaining and huffing and puffing...but in the end, the reality is, teaching things that are not justified through evidence/reason, is teaching ignorance, plan and simple.
 
 Many people have faith-based religious convictions and practices. They do not need to conflict with science and reason, and in many cases, do not. Enjoying community events, discussions, and offering emotional and physical support to others is certainly not the issue here. Making claims on faith does not conflict with reason, if it's understood it's based on faith, and intentionally NOT science. However, to argue AGAINST science, based on such faith, is the problem with this creation argument, and ultimately, weakens one's faith, since it places faith in the grasp of reason, the place it's specifically designed NOT to be a part of.
 
 Thank reason, and hard working humans (both religious and non-religious) that most of our education systems teach knowledge, not ignorance.

 I agree and disagree.
 
 On The Origin Of Species is mostly of historical interest and would not be a good place to start. Darwin actually proposed several theories in his book, 5 according to Ernst Mayr. Each of these can be (and has been) considered, tested and verified on its own. But as you imply, Darwin had no knowledge of the mechanics of heredity. In any biology course the mechanics of heredity are covered in an early chapter, and in advanced studies, a course in genetics precedes a course in evolution.
 
 However, evolution is much more than just genetics and inheritance. It is more than just the way DNA in inherited over time. The definition of biological evolution is changes in the heritable makeup of populations over time. The theories of evolution explain why those changes take place. Some of those changes have to do with the way DNA is inherited, i.e., some mutations are mistakes in the duplication of chromosomes. And recombination certainly has to do with the inheritence of DNA. But gene flow is a different matter and has more to do with the movement of populations than with inheritence alone. Natural selection is defined as differential reproductive success, but is not about reproduction but the action of the environment on populations. I guess sexual selection could be said to be about how DNA is inherited since it deals with how various organisms choose their mates. Finally, genetic drift is random action whereby some characteristics are increased or decreased. This is true in small, isolated populations.
 
Most modern biological research involves evolution to at least some degree, mainly though homology modelling - because we know that species are related and that they have evolved from a common ancestor you can look at similar genes in model orgnanisms (like mice, yeast or flatworms) and draw conclusions that will apply to humans.
